text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text occupying lower two-thirds of the page, with a large historiated miniature above. Text begins with a historiated initial “I” directly below the image. Elaborate acanthus vine scrolls, grotesques and small fauna fill the wide margins. The hierarchy places the miniature as focal point, the illuminated initial next, then the text block.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with precise angular letterforms, extensive use of abbreviations and punctus marks

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf marks divine elements (halo, frame). Deep ultramarine covers sky and Mary’s mantle, signifying her sanctity. Red vermillion clothes the executioners, heightening drama. White highlights model flesh and drapery. The border alternates blue and red leaves with green accents, creating rhythmic decoration. Pigments remain vivid, with minimal oxidation.

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen outlines in brown ink, varying line weight for emphasis
drawing_technique.shading_method: Layered brush-applied pigments with subtle gradations and white highlights on drapery
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping figures rather than true linear perspective

content_theme.scene_description: The miniature shows Christ at center, seated on a grassy mound, bound and wearing only a white loincloth. A cruciform halo surrounds his head. To his left, a kneeling executioner in a red tunic raises a hammer to drive a nail into a cross beam; behind him, the Virgin Mary in a deep ultramarine mantle mourns, hand to cheek. To Christ’s right, another executioner in red and green holds a nail or pliers. A third figure in the background adjusts an upright cross timber. The ground is painted verdant green, and the sky in rich ultramarine. Figures overlap to suggest shallow spatial recession, Christ slightly elevated. Drapery folds are indicated by brush shading and linear hatching. The executioners wear contemporary late-medieval tunics, hose and pointed shoes; Mary’s mantle has fine white highlights. Gold leaf frames the scene and accents key elements.

secular: Kneeling executioner in red tunic with hammer
Executioner in red tunic and green hat holding nail

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with uniform thickness and smooth, well-pumiced surface; ruled for text and image
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight flaking of red in margins; minor cockling at corners; evidence of contemporary lower-margin repair
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf frame

secondary_functions: Aide-memoire for meditation on the Passion
functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual noble patron (book of hours for personal prayer)

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This illuminated page, likely produced in a late fifteenth-century Parisian workshop, exemplifies the International Gothic style’s refined elegance and devotional focus. The use of costly ultramarine and burnished gold leaf signals a high-status commission for private meditation on the Passion. The historiated miniature, dominated by the centralized figure of Christ and framed by an acanthus vine border, invites intimate engagement with the scene of suffering. The masterful combination of fluid pen outlines, layered brush shading and white highlights attests to sophisticated workshop practices, with underdrawing visible under ultraviolet examination. Iconographically, the instruments of Christ’s Passion—hammer, nails, cross beams—are prominent, reinforcing the text’s plea for mercy in the adjacent office of the Passion. Marginal grotesques and a heron-like bird enliven the composition, reflecting the period’s fondness for whimsical embellishment. Compared to contemporary manuscripts such as the Hours of Étienne Chevalier, this page shares similar border vocabulary yet displays a more dynamic spatial overlap among figures. Theologically, the isolated Passion scene fosters affective piety, allowing the private viewer to contemplate Christ’s redemptive act without Old Testament typological scenes. As both a devotional tool and a luxury artifact, this leaf embodies the convergence of artistry, theology and patronal display in late medieval Europe.
